awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Risk Analysis System for Collision Avoidance with Wildlife
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a traffic safety data analytics platform that will help reduce the injuries, property damage, trauma, and environmental impact caused by wildlife-vehicle collisions (WVCs). According to public insurance and US DOT sources, over 1.3 million WVCs occur every year in the US, causing over $20B in losses for insurers, DOTs, and freight haulers. Preliminary statistical analysis indicated the effectiveness of a novel statistical model in predicting the likelihood of encountering a large animal on a roadway, and the likelihood of a collision. Extensive customer discovery with public safety managers, auto insurance claims managers, truckers, and passenger drivers, indicated widespread and financial and safety needs to reduce WVCs. Commercialization of the proposed technology as a service will enable public safety managers to understand risk factors in their districts, and preemptively and selectively deploy safety countermeasures for drivers.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a suite of statistical analytics algorithms that predict the likelihood of a driver witnessing an animal on the road, the likelihood of hitting the animal, and the potential severity of the collision (property damage, light injury, serious injury, or fatality). These proposed risk models fuse data feeds from historical crashes, past and predictive weather data, and road and surface data. The proposed technology also includes internet of things (IoT) devices, called RADs: Roadside Animal Deterrents. The proposed algorithms may determine where to install the RADs, and also evaluate changes in crash statistics over time. The technology may enable public roadway managers to keep their roads safe, maintained, and properly operating.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on a suite of statistical analytics algorithms, which predict: the likelihood of a driver witnessing an animal on the road; the likelihood of hitting the animal; and the injury-severity of the collision.  These risk models fuse data feeds of historical crashes, past and predictive weather data, and road and surface data.  The technology also includes Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices, called RADs: Roadside Animal Deterrent.  The algorithms can determine where to install the RADs, and also evaluate changes in crash statistics over time.  The main goal of the I-corps award was to validate our business value proposition through intensive and comprehensive customer discovery process.  Specifically: to define the customer segment of the proposed traffic safety innovation; to determine product-market fit with said customer segment; and to validate or invalidate our business assumptions.

During the lifetime of this project, we interviewed 119 customers, including scientists, engineers from local and regional roadway agencies, academics, non-profit coalitions, truck-fleet managers, and truckers.  After the customer interview and market investigation, our key activities shifted to testing, analytics of product effectiveness, public awareness campaign, and point of sales.  

In summary, from our I-corps experience, our value propositions became: to reduce collision costs, prevent small businesses from going out of business due to out-of-service trucks, prevent injuries in light- and medium-duty trucks, help prevent liability lawsuits, reduce wind drag and increase fuel economy for trucks, and reduce stress/damage/injuries for drivers.  This led to also shift our customer relationships to include industry events on safety and logistics, social media community, and logistics and regional trucking association conferences.  We also realized that our channels should instead include chrome shops, truckers' unions, andB2B sales (directly to fleet managers); and our customer segments should include owner operators, independent truckers, CEO and safety managers of rural fleets or small fleets (5-50 trucks) or medium fleets (150-400 trucks).  

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2023
Modified by: Panagiotis Anastasopoulos
